scenario: Berkshire Hathaway, a multinational conglomerate led by Warren Buffett, owns shares of the Vanguard S&P 500 ETF (VOO) and the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY). The Vanguard S&P 500 ETF has net assets of $1.37 trillion and an expense ratio of 0.03%. It tracks the S&P 500 index, which holds 500 of the top U.S. large-cap stocks and has a long track record of delivering strong results, averaging 10.5% since its introduction in 1957. The S&P 500 index has a modest dividend yield of 1.2% and a P/E of 28. Billionaire investors, including Warren Buffett, have praised the S&P 500 ETF for its low-cost option and its ability to deliver solid growth. The S&P 500 ETF is a diversified investment option that offers a mix of growth and value stocks, and it is considered a low-risk investment compared to picking individual stocks. Berkshire Hathaway's investment in the S&P 500 ETF is a significant portion of its portfolio, with Warren Buffett advising that 90% of his estate's wealth should be invested in a low-cost S&P 500 index fund after he dies.
